_exec_summary.SummaryText:
TETRA MICRONUTRIENTS

AMMONIATED ZINC PROCESS



Risk Management Plan





EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



40 CFR 68.155(a)    The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary Source



The stationary source covered by this Risk Management Plan is the Tetra Micronutrients' (Tetra) Ammoniated Zinc Process.  Tetra a privately owned micronutrient manufacturing facility in Fairbury, Nebraska.  Tetra maintains all of the equipment in its process by employing the best engineering practices in the industry.  Tetra strives for excellence in the facility operations and for full compliance with all local, state, and federal laws and regulations.



Meeting environmental requirements is part of Tetra's policies and by developing and maintaining this Risk Management Program Tetra is complying with the Federal Accident Prevention Provisions (40 CFR Part 68) and the Risk Management Program defined in it.  Tetra is committed to the accidental release prevention program.  



Tetra maintains a thorough detailed Emergency Response Plan designated specifically for an ammonia release for the Ammoniated Zinc Process.  The plan will be reviewed with response organizations and others.  



50 CFR 68.155(b)    The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled



The Tetra'a Ammoniated Zinc Process produced ammoniated zinc by feeding water, zinc chloride, citric acid, and anhydrous ammonia into a low-pressure reactor.  Alternating additions of zinc chloride, citric acid, water, and anhydrous ammonia continue until the batch is complete.  The primary function of the anhydrous ammonia is to raise the pH of the water/zinc chloride solution.



Liquid anhydrous ammonia is stored in a pressure vessel under ambient temperature.  The pressure vessel has a 30,000 gallon or 150,000 pound capacity with a maximum fill level at 85%.  As the result, the normal operating amount of ammonia stored in the Tetra Micronutrient is 25,000 gallons or 125,000 pounds.  



40 CFR 68.155(c)

The Worst-Case Release Scenario(s) and the Alternative Release Scenario(s), Including Administrative Controls and Mitigation Measures to Limit the Distances for Each Reported Scenario



Under the Risk Management Program, an offisite consequence analysis is required for an accidental release of a regulated substance.  In Tetra's case, anhydrous ammonia is the regulated substance.  Modeling of a worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario for anhydrous ammonia are required for offsite consequence analysis under Program 2.



EPA has defined a worst-case release as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel that results in the greatest distance to a specified endpoint.  The largest quantity is determined by taking into account administrative controls that limit the quantity of a substance that can be stored or processed in a vessel at any one time, or alternatively, procedures that occasionally allow the vessel to store greater than usual quantities.   EPA defined alternative release scenarios to be any release that is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario and that reaches an endpoint offsite.



For offsite consequence analysis, the movement and dispersion of a regulated substance release to the atmosphere is predicted using the computer model called Areal Locations of Hazardous Atmosphere (ALOHA).  ALOHA predicts pollutant concentration downwind from the source, taking into consideration the physical characteristics of ammonia, the physical characteristics of the site, weather condition, and the circumstance of the release.



40 CFR 68.155(d)    The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Tetra Micronutrient has a Release Prevention Program in place to prevent accidental releases of hazardous materials at this facility.  The Release Prevention Program includes:



* Safety Information (SI)

Tetra will develop and keep current, working copies of SI documentat

ion including information pertaining to hazards of the process, the technology of the process and the equipment of the process.  This information will be used to inform employees and contractors.



* Hazard Review (HR)

Tetra is committed to performing HR to identify, evaluate and control hazards associated with the Ammoniated Zinc Process and to comply with the requirements of 40 CFR 68.50.



* Operating Procedures (OPs)

Tetra has developed OPs for the Ammoniated Zinc Process and will updated the Ops as required.



* Training

Tetra is committed to providing its employees with comprehensive training to assure that the work force can perform their duties safely, efficiently and effectively.



* Maintenance

Tetra utilized a preventive maintenance scheduling software to track daily maintenance need.  The preventive maintenance includes pressure vessels and storage tanks, piping systems and ancillary equipment, relief and vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance procedures are developed or promulgated by equipment vendors, federal or state regulations, or industry codes.



* Incident Investigation

The current Tetra Micronutrients Emergency Ammonia Release Response Plan is a component of the Incident Investigation process.  Incident reporting procedures are well defined.  Responsibilities, titles and phone numbers are given in a highly readable document.



40 CFR 668.155(e)    The Five-Year Accident History



The five-year accident history involves an examination of the effects of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the five years prior to the submission of a Risk Management Program.  The five-year accident history covers:



* A release of anhydrous ammonia from Tetra Micronutrient that caused at least one of the following:

1. Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (40 CFR part 68.42(a)); or

2. Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or shelte

ring in place (40 CFR part 68.42(a)).



The Tetra's Ammoniated Zinc Process is a newly constructed facility.  There have been no releases that conform with accidental release requirements that caused death, injuries, property damage, or environmental damage either on or off site.



40 CFR 68.155(f)    The Emergency Response Program



Tetra Micronutrients has a thorough detailed Emergency Ammonia Release Response Plan designated specifically for an ammonia release from the Ammoniated Zinc Process.  The plan will be reviewed with response organizations and others.



40 CFR 68.155(g)    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Tetra Micronutrient's will follow up on all of the recommendations in the recently completed Risk Management Program in a timely manner.  Any recommendations resulting from the revalidation of the Risk Management Program in the future will be dealt with in the same manner.
